title: How to Build Raised Vegetable Garden Boxes

steps.headline: Find the location where you plan to put the box.
steps.description: When you have decided the place, position the box, and dig out holes for the corner post. These posts can simply be placed on top of the soil or they can be rooted in the ground several inches or more. This is up to your preference. Just plan ahead. Expert Answer						Q				When asked, "When is a raised bed a good idea?" Steve Masley																			Organic Vegetable Gardener										Steve Masley has been designing and maintaining organic vegetable gardens in the San Francisco Bay Area for over 30 years. He is a Organic Gardening Consultant and Founder of Grow-It-Organically, a website that teaches clients and students the ins and outs of organic vegetable gardening. In 2007 and 2008, Steve taught the Local Sustainable Agriculture Field Practicum at Stanford University. EXPERT ADVICE				The team at Grow it Organically answered: "When you're working on an in-ground garden, it's harder on your back because of the angle. If you have any physical issues, a raised bed is just much easier to work, and you can do a lot more in a day."

steps.headline: Prepare your wood posts.
steps.description: Use 4x4 pieces of lumber. These will be used for the corners of the boxes. Cut them to be at least the same height or several inches deeper than the box. If your boxes are going to be longer than 8', you will want add to center posts on the long sides.

steps.headline: Cut the side walls.
steps.description: Using 2x4s, cut boards for the two long sides, equal to the distance from the far edge of one corner post to the far edge of the other. Cut the short end boards to be equal to the distance between the far edges of the posts, plus the ends of the long side boards.

steps.headline: Drill the boards into place.
steps.description: Use outdoor appropriate screws; 1"-1 1/2" or decking screws work well. Drill through the boards directly into the posts.

steps.headline: Place a barrier cloth.
steps.description: Once the box is set, line the box with 1/2" hardware cloth to keep out pests and varmint. Staple or screw the hardware cloth to the sides.

steps.headline: Place weed cloth.
steps.description: Next, place some weed cloth on top of the hardware cloth. Staple that to the sides of the box. This is to keep the weeds from growing from below.

steps.headline: Add in your soil.
steps.description: Bring in some planting mix for soil. It is usually measured in cubic feet. Use a wheelbarrow or park close to the box and start filling it up. Stand on it to pack it down. Leave about 2 inches (5.1 cm) from the top.

steps.headline: Have fun watching your garden grow!
steps.description: Make sure to fertilize the soil or rotate types of plants in the boxes to keep the soil fresh. Plan to grow plants that suit the season of the year as well.

steps.headline: Find an old filing cabinet.
steps.description: You want to find an older filing cabinet with a solid bottom. You don't want one that's rusty or in bad shape though.

steps.headline: Prepare the filing cabinet.
steps.description: Remove the drawers and also the tracks if you can. Sand out the inside and remove as much paint (if there is any inside) as you can. Tip the filing cabinet so that the back is now the base and place the cabinet where you want your new veggie bed to be.

steps.headline: Repaint the outside.
steps.description: Using outdoor safe spray paint, repaint the outside a fun new color to start bringing the cabinet back to life. Look for spray paints that are graded to stick well to smooth metal or enamel.

steps.headline: Line the cabinet.
steps.description: Get a lining material and line the inside of your cabinet. Weed liner is good for this. It will help keep the metal from becoming damaged too quickly.

steps.headline: Add your drainage material.
steps.description: Unless you drill holes in the new bottom of the cabinet, you'll need to place several inches of filler material at the bottom of the cabinet to allow drainage. Start with a base, single layer of river rock, add a 3" layer of gravel, and then add a 3" layer of sand.

steps.headline: Fill with planting soil.
steps.description: Now, fill your filing cabinet with planting soil. Leave about 2" at the top. More soil can be filled in if needed once your plants are put in.

steps.headline: Grow your veg!
steps.description: Grow or transplant your vegetable plants. Enjoy your colorful, modern garden box!

steps.headline: Purchase the necessary bricks.
steps.description: Think about the size and height that you want the garden bed to be and then buy the amount of garden brick that you find appropriate for that size. You can buy more later if you need it, so don't overbuy.

steps.headline: Level the ground.
steps.description: Level the ground where you plan to put the bed.

steps.headline: Lay out the bricks layer by layer.
steps.description: Lay out the first layer of the garden bricks, adjusting for size and making sure that the bricks fit snugly. Then, move to the next layer and the next until the wall is at the height you desire. Stagger the bricks in a way that looks good to you.

steps.headline: Line the garden bed.
steps.description: Add a thick liner or a heavy duty weed liner to the inside of the box. Leave extra material coming up over the edge. The extra will be trimmed away later.

steps.headline: Fill the garden bed.
steps.description: Fill the box with high quality soil and fertilizers if you want them. Leave extra space at the top (roughly 2").

steps.headline: Plant your vegetables!
steps.description: Enjoy your new garden beds!
